Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Mechanism and Genome-Wide Regulation of Genes and Transposable Elements by Epigenetically Active Small Interfering RNAs

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit. Transposable elements (TEs) are mobile and can insert into genes, causing mutations. To guard against this mutagenic potential, organisms have evolved mechanisms to repress transcription of TEs. Recently the PI's laboratory has discovered that when TEs are transcriptionally activated in Arabidopsis plants, many of the TE transcripts are processed into large quantities of novel small RNAs that are termed epigenetically active small interfering RNAs (easiRNAs). These easiRNAs are hypothesized to be responsible for the initiation of silencing of active TEs, the establishment of epigenetic regulation in the form of DNA methylation, as well as production of large-scale transcriptomic changes. The major goal of this project is to explore how easiRNA biogenesis is triggered and to understand the multiple biological functions of easiRNA production. Investigation of these processes is critical for understanding how the genome maintains integrity and survives TE transcriptional activation, as well as how a cell can recognize what needs to be expressed (cellular genes) from what should be silenced (TEs). Moreover, easiRNA influence on multiple cellular functions may explain some important agricultural phenomena, and therefore it is fundamental to understand these mechanisms and which genes are affected.

Broader Impacts. This project will support training and mentoring of undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral scientists. In addition, the project will include two independent activities designed to best integrate the PI's research, teaching, and diversity outreach components. First, the PI's current Young Scholars Program Biology Enhancement Workshop, which is taught to 7th grade students from the urban Columbus public school system, will be continued and leveraged to generate the Young Scholars Program Biology Internships. In this novel program middle school underrepresented minorities in STEM disciplines will be integrated into the PI?s laboratory and get real biology laboratory experience and advance biological discovery while engaged in training and learning exercises. Once the internship is completed, the student will automatically transition into a scientific mentoring program with the PI. This program will be expanded to include other PIs and will impact the community by providing a professional scientific research experience with extended mentoring to underrepresented students. Second, the PI will fully integrate the research in this project into an annual upper-division undergraduate laboratory course. With help from Course Design Institute of the Ohio State University Center for the Advancement of Teaching, the PI will integrate specific sub-aims from this project into the undergraduate laboratory curriculum and education. The original data produced from the course experiments will be published by the class in an undergraduate research journal and will be used directly by the PI. This course will leverage the Department of Molecular Genetics teaching infrastructure to teach and train undergraduate students molecular biology, while also exciting students about advancing scientific discovery.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transposable elements are fragments of DNA that occupy half of the total human genetic material (the human genome). These transposable elements are found in the genomes of nearly all multicellular organisms, and can occupy up to 85% of plant genomes. Transposable elements have the unique ability to move around, or transpose, from one region of a genome to another. The act of transposing is inherently problematic for a cell, as it causes mutations that lead to disease, altered growth patterns and reduced agricultural productivity. Cells control transposition by identifying transposable elements in the genome, and silencing their expression and activity. Most transposable elements in plant and animal genomes are found in this silenced, and thus benign, state. 

Although many projects have focused on the regulation of transposable elements, researchers have primarily investigated already silenced elements. This project was unique in its specific focus on new or active transposable elements, and in particular how the cell targets these transposing elements for silencing. Using the powerfully manipulatable experimental organism Arabidopsis (a small plant), we previously discovered that the cell degrades active transposable element RNA into a specialized class of ‘epigenetically active small interfering RNAs (easiRNAs)’. These small RNA molecules, 21-22 nucleotides in length, act as sequence specific guides for protein complexes. This project aimed to determine the cellular consequence of active transposable elements through the determination of the function, biogenesis and genome-wide role of transposable element easiRNAs. This project also leveraged the cutting-edge research program to educate and train post-doctoral scholars, graduate students, undergraduates and middle school students from the local Columbus school district. 

Directly through the research performed under this project, we discovered or co-discovered five genome-wide functions of transposable element easiRNAs: 1) to target the degradation of transposable element RNA transcripts, 2) to target matching gene sequences for degradation of genic RNA, 3) to travel to and repress any transposable element activity that occurs in the male germ (sperm) cells (thereby guarding against transposition in the next generation), 4) to determine the parental dosage ratio in the developing endosperm for proper seed development, and 5) to target transposable elements for the first round of RNA-directed DNA methylation. This last discovery was the focus of intense research to characterize the role of easiRNAs in directing the first ‘flagging’ of transposable element sequences with the molecular marks of DNA methylation and histone modifications. The cell adds these flags / marks to the DNA to denote that this region is a transposable element and should not produce an active RNA transcript. These flags can be read by the cell that establishes these marks, as well as by future cells produced from division of the original cell, in a process called ‘epigenetic’ inheritance. 

On a broad level, our results have generated a deep biological understanding of the cellular changes that occur when transposable elements are active, and how the cell understands these cues to target the transposable element for silencing. Through this research we have determined that easiRNAs function in both transposable element and gene regulation, and that there is a spatial and temporal component to this regulation that centers around fertilization (during gamete and endosperm regulation). This project has significantly altered our understanding of the function of transposable element activity, the small RNAs they produce, and how transposable elements are first targeted for epigenetic silencing. On a more detailed level, this project resulting in the characterization of the precise molecular mechanisms responsible for easiRNA biogenesis and what initially triggers easiRNA production. The data produced for this project is available through open-access publications and publicly-accessible data repositories. 

This project in part trained four post-doctoral scholars, five Ph.D. graduate students, 65 undergraduate students in the biological sciences and 80 middle school students. The undergraduates were trained through the integration of this research plan into the Department of Molecular Genetics laboratory curriculum at The Ohio State University. Students gained experience in molecular biology through the analysis of transposable element activity, preparing them for future research careers in graduate or medical school. Middle school students were trained in the Scientific Method through the creation of a Biology Enhancement Workshop within the larger Young Scholars Program, which is run by the Office of Diversity and Inclusion at The Ohio State University. The Young Scholars Program provides financial assistance to academically-talented students who are first-generation college-boundand originally from the city of Columbus school district, while now the program has expanded to the full state of Ohio. Through this project, training in the sciences was introduced to excite students about careers in STEM fields.
